metadata.titleEn: Analysis of the status of social  frailty in Chinese older adults with  cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases: a national cross-sectional study dataset (2015.08-2022.09)
metadata.description:
Background: Social frailty is one type of frailty. Physical frailty with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases (CCVD) have been studied a lot, but less research on social frailty.
Objectives: To study the prevalence, related risk factors and regional differences of social frailty with CCVD in Chinese older adults.
Methods: SSAPUR was a national cross-sectional survey. Participants aged 60 years or older were recruited in August 2015. Demographic data and information regarding family, health and medical conditions, living environment conditions, social participation, spiritual and cultural life, and health condition were obtained. Social frailty was assessed in five areas (HALFE Social Frailty Index) including inability to help others, limited social participation, loneliness, financial difficulty, and living alone. The prevalence of CCVD with social frailty, related risk factors and regional differences in CCVD with social frailty were studied.
Results: A total of 222,179 participants were enrolled. 28.4% of them had CCVD history. The prevalence of social frailty in the CCVD group was 16.03%. In CCVD participants, compared with the group without social frailty, there were significant differences in gender, age, urban-rural distribution, ethnicity, marital status, and education levels in the social frailty group. Significant differences were also found in physical exercise participation, health status, cataract, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hospitalization within 1 year, self-assessed health status, crutch or wheelchair usage, urinary and fecal incontinence, need for care from others, fall history, housing satisfaction, and self-assessed happiness in the social frailty group. Women with CCVD had a higher prevalence of social frailty than men. By age in CCVD with social frailty, the highest prevalence was found in participants 75-79 years old. The prevalence of CCVD was significant difference between social frailty in urban and rural group. The prevalence of social frailty with CCVD was significantly different in different regions. The highest prevalence was 20.4% in southwest area, and the lowest prevalence was 12.5% in northeast with area.
Conclusion: The prevalence of social frailty among the CCVD older adults is high. Factors such as gender, age, region, urban-rural residence, and the state of the disease may be associated with social frailty.

background: It is estimated that over 300 million Chinese people will be 60 years of age or older by 2025. With this aging demographic, the prevalence of chronic diseases like cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases (CCVDs) and frailty will increase. Frailty describes a state of vulnerability due to an age-related decline in several physiological systems and is associated with a considerably increased risk of falling, disability, hospitalization, and mortality. Existing research on risk factors of frailty mainly focuses on sociodemographic, physiological, and biological risk factors. In recent years, frailty has evolved from a concept focused on physical frailty to one that encompasses multiple health aspects (physical, psychological, and social). Social frailty is a risk factor for long-term mortality and disability, and has a prevalence of approximately 18%–30% among community-dwelling older adults. Frailty is believed to have a bidirectional effect on cardiovascular diseases. Emerging evidence suggests that frailty is a risk factor for CCVDs, even after accounting for subclinical atherosclerosis. Conversely, CCVD risk factors and risk scores may predict frailty: frailty is associated with a higher risk of CCVD prevalence. Therefore, frailty can be considered both a consequence of and a potential risk factor for CCVDs.
research objective: The prevalence of social frailty in Chinese older adults with CCVDs has not been reported. Therefore, the characteristics of the older adults with CCVDs combined with social frailty need to be investigated. This study uses data from the fourth Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban/Rural China (SSAPUR) conducted in 2015 and provides reference information for early interventions for CCVD patients with social frailty.
methods: Data were obtained from the database of the fourth SSAPUR, conducted by the China National Committee on Ageing in 2015. The characteristics of subjects with and without social frailty were compared using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) for normal-distributed quantitative data and the Chi-square test for categorical data. Multivariate logistic regression was performed to estimate the adjusted odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of variables associated with social frailty. All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 24.0 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, United States).
dataset: Data were obtained from the database of the fourth SSAPUR, conducted by the China National Committee on Ageing in 2015. Chinese citizens aged 60 or above were surveyed to compile the largest database of older people in China. The SSAPUR covered 31 provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities, and the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps, including 466 counties (districts), 1,864 townships (sub-districts), and 7,456 village (residential) committees. The number of collected samples was 2,24,142.
findings: The prevalence of social frailty was 16.03% in the CCVD group and 14.9% in the non-CCVD group, with significant differences between the two groups (p < 0.001). Women with CCVDs had a higher prevalence of social frailty than men with CCVDs. The highest prevalence of social frailty in the CCVD group was observed in participants aged 75–79. There existed significant differences in the prevalence of social frailty in CCVD patients with hypertension and CCVD patients with diabetes. The prevalence of social frailty in CCVD patients also varied based on region: Southwest China had the highest prevalence of social frailty (20.4%) and the Northeast had the lowest prevalence rate (12.5%). The prevalence of social frailty combined with CCVDs was 11.8% in urban areas and 21.3% in rural areas, with significant differences. Multivariate regression analysis showed that gender, age, educational level, marital status, living in an urban vs. rural environment, physical exercise, number of comorbid chronic diseases, lung diseases, cancer, wheelchair usage, fecal incontinence, fall history, housing satisfaction, self-assessed happiness, and self-care ability were all associated with social frailty in CCVD patients.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to assess social frailty among older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases in China?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in this field is the fourth Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban/Rural China (SSAPUR), conducted in 2015. This nationwide cross-sectional survey collected demographic, health, and social data from participants aged 60 and above across various regions in China.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that could be used to study the prevalence of social frailty in older Chinese adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the database from the fourth SSAPUR, which includes data from 224,142 Chinese citizens aged 60 or above. This dataset covers various sociodemographic and health-related variables necessary for studying social frailty in this population.

Definition.Question: What does 'social frailty' mean in the context of studying older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Definition.Answer: Social frailty refers to a state of vulnerability characterized by limited social resources and interactions, which can impact an individual's ability to interact with others and participate in society. In the study of older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, social frailty is assessed through factors like inability to help others, limited social participation, feelings of loneliness, economic hardship, and living alone.

Definition.Question: What is the HALFE social frailty index, and how is it used in data collection for assessing social frailty among elderly individuals with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Definition.Answer: The HALFE social frailty index is a tool used to evaluate social frailty among elderly individuals by assessing five specific factors: inability to help others, limited social participation, feelings of loneliness, economic hardship, and living alone. This index helps researchers quantify the level of social frailty in individuals, particularly those with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, by collecting data on these aspects during surveys or interviews.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for assessing social frailty in older adults with cardiovascular diseases differ from those used for physiological frailty?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection for social frailty involves assessing factors such as social participation, loneliness, economic hardship, and living conditions, while physiological frailty focuses on physical health metrics and biological factors.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the regional differences in social frailty prevalence among older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases across different areas in China?
Interpretation.Answer: The regional differences in social frailty prevalence indicate significant variability, with the highest prevalence in Southwest China and the lowest in the Northeast. This suggests potential underlying factors such as economic, cultural, or healthcare access differences that may influence social frailty levels. Understanding these factors can help tailor interventions to regional needs.

Interpretation.Question: How might the observed associations between specific demographic and health characteristics and social frailty inform future data collection methods for studies on elderly populations with cardiovascular conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: The associations between characteristics like gender, age, and comorbidities with social frailty suggest that future data collection methods should incorporate comprehensive demographic and health information. This could enhance the ability to identify at-risk groups and improve the accuracy of social frailty assessments in elderly populations with cardiovascular conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variations in social frailty prevalence when collecting data from different regions in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The prevalence of social frailty in CCVD patients varies based on region, with Southwest China having the highest prevalence and the Northeast having the lowest. This regional variation could be influenced by differences in cultural, socio-economic, and healthcare factors affecting the older population.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might social frailty be more prevalent among women with CCVDs compared to men in data collection efforts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The higher prevalence of social frailty among women with CCVDs compared to men could be due to gender-related differences in social roles, support systems, health-seeking behavior, or other socio-demographic factors that are captured during data collection.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying causes could lead to the discrepancies in social frailty prevalence between urban and rural areas in a dataset involving older adults with CCVD?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The discrepancies in social frailty prevalence between urban and rural areas could be due to differences in access to healthcare, social support networks, lifestyle factors, and economic conditions, which are often captured in data collection methodologies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the inclusion of demographic variables in a dataset have on understanding the social frailty of older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including demographic variables such as gender, age, education level, and marital status allows for the identification of significant differences in social frailty prevalence among different groups, such as higher prevalence among women and those aged 75-79, providing a more nuanced understanding of social frailty.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the regional distribution of data collection sites affect the observed prevalence of social frailty in older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The regional distribution of data collection sites reveals significant differences in social frailty prevalence, with the highest observed in Southwest China and the lowest in Northeast China, indicating that geographical factors may play a role in social frailty outcomes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a cross-sectional survey design in assessing social frailty among older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Causal Consequence.Answer: A cross-sectional survey design provides a snapshot of social frailty prevalence and associated factors at a specific time, allowing for the identification of correlations between variables such as gender, age, and living environment, but it limits the ability to establish causal relationships over time.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the main objective of collecting data on social frailty among older Chinese adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objective is to investigate the prevalence, associated risk factors, and regional differences of social frailty in older Chinese adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases to provide reference information for early interventions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to compare characteristics of individuals with and without social frailty in the context of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to compare these characteristics to identify significant differences and associations, which can help in understanding the risk factors and inform targeted interventions for individuals with social frailty in the context of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary purpose of using multivariate logistic regression in analyzing data related to social frailty and cardiovascular diseases?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary purpose of using multivariate logistic regression is to estimate the adjusted odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals of variables associated with social frailty, allowing for a more comprehensive understanding of the factors contributing to social frailty among individuals with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to assess social frailty in older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases across different regions of China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To assess social frailty in older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, one can utilize a nationwide cross-sectional survey approach like the SSAPUR. This involves collecting demographic, health, and lifestyle data and assessing social frailty using a framework such as the HALFE social frailty index. This index evaluates aspects like inability to help others, limited social participation, loneliness, economic hardship, and living alone. Statistical analyses, including one-way ANOVA and Chi-square tests, can be used to compare characteristics, while logistic regression can estimate variables associated with social frailty.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers ensure comprehensive data coverage and representation when conducting large-scale surveys on older populations with chronic diseases in China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers can achieve comprehensive data coverage and representation by designing surveys that include a wide range of geographic locations, such as provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities across China. The SSAPUR survey, for example, covered 31 provinces and multiple districts, ensuring a diverse sample. Additionally, including various settings such as urban and rural environments helps in capturing the demographic diversity. It's also essential to collect data on different domains including health status, social participation, and living conditions to ensure a holistic view of the population.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to perform a statistical analysis of social frailty data in older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To perform a statistical analysis of social frailty data, the following steps are necessary: first, data must be collected and preprocessed to ensure accuracy and completeness. Quantitative data should be checked for normal distribution. Analyses such as one-way ANOVA can be used for normally distributed data, while Chi-square tests can handle categorical data. Multivariate logistic regression is then employed to determine the odds ratios and confidence intervals for variables associated with social frailty. The use of statistical software like SPSS 24.0 is recommended for these analyses.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of demographic and health-related data in nationwide surveys enable the identification of regional differences in social frailty among elderly populations with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular conditions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of such data in nationwide surveys allows for comparisons across different regions and demographic groups by providing a detailed dataset that includes variables like age, gender, urban-rural residence, and specific health conditions. This comprehensive approach enables researchers to identify regional differences in social frailty, as demonstrated by the SSAPUR survey's findings of varying prevalence rates across different Chinese regions.

Expectation.Question: What factors might contribute to discrepancies between anticipated and observed prevalence rates of social frailty in older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies might arise due to variations in demographic characteristics such as gender, age, and urban-rural living conditions, as well as the presence of comorbid conditions like hypertension and diabetes, which are significantly different between groups with and without CCVDs.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using multivariate logistic regression as a data analysis method for investigating social frailty among older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multivariate logistic regression is effective for investigating social frailty as it allows for the estimation of adjusted odds ratios and confidence intervals for variables associated with social frailty. This method provides a structured way to analyze the relationships between multiple variables and social frailty, offering insights into the significant factors influencing frailty among older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset can effectively capture the multifaceted aspects of social frailty among older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset from the fourth SSAPUR survey includes comprehensive demographic, health, and social data from Chinese citizens aged 60 or above. It evaluates social frailty by considering factors like limited social participation, loneliness, financial difficulty, and living alone, using the HALFE social frailty index.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and describe the data collection methods used to gather demographic, health, and social information from older adults with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data were collected through the fourth Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban/Rural China (SSAPUR), which included demographic information, health and disease status, living environment, social participation, and mental and cultural life. The survey covered 31 provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities, and the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps, encompassing 466 counties, 1,864 townships, and 7,456 village committees. The database compiled from this survey included information from Chinese citizens aged 60 or above.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose potential strategies for enhancing datasets related to social frailty and cardiovascular diseases among older adults to improve early intervention outcomes.
Request/Directive.Answer: To enhance datasets, strategies could include integrating longitudinal data to track changes over time, incorporating qualitative data to capture the subjective aspects of social frailty, expanding the scope to include more diverse regions and underrepresented groups, and using advanced statistical methods such as multivariate regression to identify complex interactions between social, demographic, and health variables. Additionally, cross-referencing with other health and social databases could provide more comprehensive insights into the factors influencing social frailty.
